EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure centered over the Desert Southwest allowed for temperatures to reach or exceed 110 degrees during the early part of July. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 18 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three heat-associated fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances and location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong area of high pressure parked over the Southwest United States led to continued excessive heat conditions across the region from the end of July into the beginning of August. Temperatures each day climbed near or above 110 degrees with a daily record high of 114 degrees being set in Phoenix on the 3rd. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 40 heat-associated fatalities occurred with this event for the beginning of August.

The 2nd longest heatwave in modern history (1900-onward) occurred across portions of NY and VT from June 18th through June 23rd. Temperatures exceeded 90 degrees for up to 6 consecutive days in portions of the St. Lawrence and Champlain Valleys. Daily High temperature records were set at Massena on June 22nd and June 23rd with high temperatures of 93 and 92 degrees respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s for many parts of the St. Lawrence Valley for six days with increasing humidity on the tail end of this stretch, bringing heat indices into the mid 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from July 29th through August 1st. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 7 to 16 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category, which was attained July 29 through July 31, to continue on August 1.  High temperatures on August 1 included 111 degrees at Picacho and Fort Thomas; 108 at Ajo, Green Valley (tie) and Willcox (record); and 105 (tie) at Douglas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level ridge of high pressure over the southwestern part of the country brought a two-day heat wave to parts of Southern California with record breaking temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some areas reported highs in the triple digits during this heat wave. The Campo COOP reported a high of 100 degrees on the 18th, breaking a daily record.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level ridge of high pressure over the southwestern part of the country brought a two-day heat wave to parts of Southern California with record breaking temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures ranging from 108 - 113 degrees occurred. The Palm Springs ASOS recorded 113 degrees on the 17th.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level ridge of high pressure over the southwestern part of the country brought a two-day heat wave to parts of Southern California with record breaking temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures in upwards of 100 degrees were reported across the Inland Empire. The Chino ASOS reported a high temperature of 106 degrees on the 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level ridge of high pressure over the southwestern part of the country brought a two-day heat wave to parts of Southern California with record breaking temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures climbed into the upper 90s and low 100s in some spots during this heat wave. Santa Ana reached 99 degrees on the 17th and Anaheim broke a daily record, reaching 96, on the 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level ridge of high pressure over the southwestern part of the country brought a two-day heat wave to parts of Southern California with record breaking temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures soared into the upper 80s to low 90s in some coastal locations. Chula Vista tied a daily record high, reaching 91 degrees on the 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level ridge of high pressure over the southwestern part of the country brought a two-day heat wave to parts of Southern California with record breaking temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures soared near 110 degrees in parts of the San Diego County Deserts, where Anza Borrego State Park tied their record daily high temperature of 110 degrees on the 17th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A mid-level ridge of high pressure over the southwestern part of the country brought a two-day heat wave to parts of Southern California with record breaking temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures soared close to 105 degrees in some spots during this heat wave. El Cajon tied its daily record of 104 degrees on the 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and high humidity combined to create heat indices of 105-110 degrees across central and southern Oklahoma on the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No heat illnesses were reported on this day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Desert Southwest remained under the influence of persistent strong high pressure during the middle part of July. During this time, temperatures peaked around 110 degrees each day. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 24 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight heat-associated fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances and location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures were experienced on October 6th with high temperatures just over 100 degrees in central Pima County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert southeast of Cowlic on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal, just over 100 degrees, occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on October 6th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male near southeast of Cowlic.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures were experienced on October 20th with high temperatures in the middle to upper 90s in central Pima County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert near the International Border west northwest of San Miguel on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal, in the middle to upper 90s, occurred on the Tohono O'odham Nation causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on October 20th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male near the International Border west northwest of San Miguel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The Desert Southwest remained under the influence of persistent strong high pressure during the middle part of July. During this time, temperatures peaked around 110 degrees each day. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 24 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fourteen heat-associated fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances and location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The 2nd longest heatwave in modern history (1900-onward) occurred across portions of NY and VT from June 18th through June 23rd. Temperatures exceeded 90 degrees for up to 6 consecutive days in portions of the St. Lawrence and Champlain Valleys. Daily High temperature records were set at Massena on June 22nd and June 23rd with high temperatures of 93 and 92 degrees respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s for many parts of the Champlain Valley for six days with increasing humidity on the tail end of this stretch, bringing heat indices into the mid 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong area of high pressure parked over the Southwest United States led to continued excessive heat conditions across the region from the end of July into the beginning of August. Temperatures each day climbed near or above 110 degrees with a daily record high of 114 degrees being set in Phoenix on the 3rd. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 40 heat-associated fatalities occurred with this event for the beginning of August.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached up to 109 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona from June 3rd through June 5th with high temperatures exceeding established records in many locations. No heat related fatalities were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 5 to 12 degrees above normal occurred in the western deserts of Pima and southeast Pinal counties, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached. A number of daily high temperature records were tied or broken. On June 3rd, Ajo set a new record high with 108 degrees while San Manuel topped out one degree shy of a record at 103 degrees. The Tucson International Airport was two shy with a high of 105. Meanwhile, Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and Picacho both reached 107 and Sells hit 106. On June 4th, Ajo tied a record with 110 degrees as did San Manuel with 104. The Tucson International Airport reached 108 degrees and Sells climbed to 107.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona from June 3rd through June 5th with high temperatures exceeding established records in many locations. No heat related fatalities were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 6 to 13 degrees above normal occurred in the valleys of Graham, Cochise and southern Greenlee counties, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached. A number of daily high temperature records were tied or broken. On June 3rd, highs included 106 degrees at both the Safford Airport and the Ag Station, 105 at Cascabel and 104 at Duncan. On June 4th, both observing locations in Safford set record highs with 108 degrees while Duncan topped out one degree shy of a record at 107. Cascabel reached 108 and San Simon hit 104. On June 5th, new record highs included 111 degrees at Safford Ag Station, 110 at Safford Airport, 108 at San Simon, 107 at Duncan and 106 at McNeal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on May 6th and 7th with high temperatures exceeding established records in many locations. No heat related fatalities were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot spring temperatures 12 to 17 degrees above normal occurred in parts of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached. Several daily high temperature records were tied or broken.  On May 6th record highs included 107 degrees at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 106 at Tucson International Airport, 104 at Ajo (tie) and Sells, 103 at Safford Ag Center, 102 at Sasabe and Benson, 100 at Nogales Airport and 98 at San Manuel.  On May 7th record highs included 108 degrees at Ajo, 104 at Green Valley, 102 at Safford Airport, 101 at Sasabe, 98 at Nogales Airport and 97 at San Manuel. Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument (107) and Picacho (105) were both shy of a record on May 7th by one degree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Record May Heat produced the instability and the mountains of the Green Mountains produced the lift to develop thunderstorms in the afternoon that very slowly moved south to north along the mountain ridges. A few storms produced wet micro-bursts that caused some tree and utility line damage. ||In addition, Record Heat was observed in VT. Daily record highs for May 27th included; Burlington at 95 degrees, Montpelier at 91 degrees, St. Johnsbury at 92 degrees and the summit of Mount Mansfield at 85 degrees. ||Burlington's high temperature was the hottest May day since records began in 1883 and the low of the day (72 degrees) was the warmest ever in May. Mount Mansfield recorded it's warmest temperature EVER at 85 degrees since records began in November 1954. Montpelier's 91 degree high was it's warmest day in May since records began in 1949.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record Heat with Daily High records broken at Burlington, Montpelier, St. Johnsbury and Mount Mansfield.  Burlington broke the warmest May temperature ever with 95 degrees.|Mount Mansfield set an ALL-TIME Record with 85 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure built into California on May 25 and May 26. This resulted in much above normal daytime temperatures on both days with some locations setting new daily records on May 26. The high then strengthened on May 27 and May 28 resulting in widespread record heat over the region on both days with highs in the San Joaquin Valley mainly between 103 and 107 on both days. Triple digit heat was also observed across portions of the Sierra foothills and Kern County Deserts. Temperatures cooled by several degrees on May 29 and lowered to below seasonal averages by May 30 as the large area high pressure broke down, and a cold front pushed through the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on May 26 and between 103 and 107 degrees on May 27 and May 28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure building over the Southwest at the end of May led to several days of excessive heat warning conditions as temperatures approached and exceeded 110 degrees. On the 29th, Phoenix topped out at 112 degrees, tying the daily high temperature record for the date. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, five heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on April 30th with high temperatures exceeding established records. No heat related fatalities were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot spring temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal occurred in parts of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached in some areas. Several new daily high temperature records were established such as 105 degrees at Ajo, 102 at Picacho, 101 at Tucson International Airport and Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 100 degrees at Sells and 99 at Safford.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of upper high pressure centered over the four corners region strengthened on June 3 and pushed an upper low off the southern California coast southwest and further away from the region. This resulted in a warming trend over the area as the mid and high level cloud cover which had been prevalent over the area during the previous few days eroded. High temperatures across the San Joaquin Valley and Sierra foothills were mainly between 99 and 103 degrees on June 3. The high remained the dominant feature over the area on June 4, and temperatures continued to rise with afternoon highs over the San Joaquin Valley and Sierra foothills mainly between 102 and 106 degrees. The high broke down and shifted east on June 5 while temperatures lowered to near normal levels as an upper level trough pushed into California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 99 and 103 degrees on June 3 and between 102 and 106 degrees on June 4.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of upper level high pressure over the Southwestern U.S. generated a prolonged heatwave from May 5th - 10th. Deserts were quite hot with some records broken. The high temperatures at Palm Springs International Airport were 101 degrees or higher for seven consecutive days (May 4-10). Even coastal areas got in on the warm weather, with San Diego International Airport hitting 85 degrees on May 6th. Coastal areas of San Diego County also experienced some dense fog on the mornings of the 7th and 8th. An accompanying shortwave trough brought some elevated convection bringing locally up to one quarter of an inch of rainfall on May 9th and another shortwave trough brought some windy conditions to the mountains and deserts with gusts 55-65 miles per hour on May 12th and 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures reached the upper 90s to 102 degrees for areas across the Inland Empire May 5th through May 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The summer heat really started showing in late June and early July. A Heat Advisory for Heat Index values over 105 degrees was issued beginning June 30th and continuing into the first few days of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon Heat Index values soared to near 110 degrees. A Heat Advisory was in effect through July 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona May 28th through the 31st with high temperatures exceeding established records in many locations. No heat-related fatalities were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 7 to 13 degrees above normal occurred in parts of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached. Several daily high temperature records were tied or broken. Record highs included: May 28th, 107 degrees (tie) at Ajo and 106 at Duncan and Safford Airport; May 29th, 108 degrees at Tucson International Airport, 107 at Fort Thomas and 102 (tie) at San Manuel; May 30th, 111 degrees at Ajo, 109 at Picacho and 106 (tie) at Anvil Ranch; May 31st, 106 degrees (tie) at Green Valley.   On May 29th, Sells reached 108 degrees, which was two degrees shy of a record while Picacho topped out at 110, just one degree off the record for the date.

On May 29th, Sells reached 108 degrees, which was two degrees shy of a record while Picacho topped out at 110, just one degree off the record for the date.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure built into Southern California on April 22nd and continued through April 30th. The deserts experienced the most extreme heat, but the coast and valleys also had multiple days with record breaking heat. Palm Springs International Airport recorded 8 days with high temperatures exceeding 101 degrees, which has not occurred since April of 1945. According to San Diego County, there were 31 heat related calls placed by residents from April 24th through the 30th, with 22 of them transported to the hospital. With onshore flow and high pressure overhead, dense fog occurred at a few coastal San Diego locations on April 25th and 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the upper 90s to 101 degrees were observed in the Inland Empire on the 24th and 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of upper level high pressure over the Southwestern U.S. generated a prolonged heatwave from May 5th - 10th. Deserts were quite hot with some records broken. The high temperatures at Palm Springs International Airport were 101 degrees or higher for seven consecutive days (May 4-10). Even coastal areas got in on the warm weather, with San Diego International Airport hitting 85 degrees on May 6th. Coastal areas of San Diego County also experienced some dense fog on the mornings of the 7th and 8th. An accompanying shortwave trough brought some elevated convection bringing locally up to one quarter of an inch of rainfall on May 9th and another shortwave trough brought some windy conditions to the mountains and deserts with gusts 55-65 miles per hour on May 12th and 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures across the lower deserts of San Diego County ranged from the low 100s to near 110 degrees May 5th through 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Leading up to the heatwave, a cooler pattern set up over Southern California, where we saw an upper level trough bring wet and windy weather on May 18th and 19th. Rain totals of up to one inch were observed in parts of the mountains and wind gusts 45-55 miles per hour in areas of the mountains and deserts. By May 26th through 28th, an upper level high pressure system set up over the western U.S. and brought the region some intense heat. Temperatures were especially hot in the deserts with readings about 10 to 15 degrees above average, where parts of the Lower Deserts reached up to 111 degrees at Palm Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures ranged from near 100 in Victorville up to 107 degrees in Lucerne Valley on the 26th to the 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Leading up to the heatwave, a cooler pattern set up over Southern California, where we saw an upper level trough bring wet and windy weather on May 18th and 19th. By May 26th through 28th, an upper level high pressure system set up over the western U.S. and brought the region some intense heat. Temperatures were especially hot in the deserts with readings about 10 to 15 degrees above average, where parts of the Lower Deserts reached up to 111 degrees at Palm Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures generally ranged from 105 to 110 degrees across the Coachella Valley each day from the 26th to the 28th, though Palm Springs did hit 111 degrees on the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona on May 6th and 7th with high temperatures exceeding established records in many locations. No heat related fatalities were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot spring temperatures 12 to 17 degrees above normal occurred in parts of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached. Several daily high temperature records were tied or broken.  On May 6th record highs included 107 degrees at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 106 at Tucson International Airport, 104 at Ajo (tie) and Sells, 103 at Safford Ag Center, 102 at Sasabe and Benson, 100 at Nogales Airport and 98 at San Manuel.  On May 7th record highs included 108 degrees at Ajo, 104 at Green Valley, 102 at Safford Airport, 101 at Sasabe, 98 at Nogales Airport and 97 at San Manuel. Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument (107) and Picacho (105) were both shy of a record on May 7th by one degree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures occurred on May 26th across the Tohono O'odham Nation. One heat-related fatality occurred east of Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on May 26th. High temperatures included 100 degrees at Sells, and 98 at Sasabe, Anvil Ranch and the Tucson International Airport. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male 2 miles east of Sells, about 2 miles south of Tohono O'odham Community College.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of upper high pressure centered over the four corners region strengthened on June 3 and pushed an upper low off the southern California coast southwest and further away from the region. This resulted in a warming trend over the area as the mid and high level cloud cover which had been prevalent over the area during the previous few days eroded. High temperatures across the San Joaquin Valley and Sierra foothills were mainly between 99 and 103 degrees on June 3. The high remained the dominant feature over the area on June 4, and temperatures continued to rise with afternoon highs over the San Joaquin Valley and Sierra foothills mainly between 102 and 106 degrees. The high broke down and shifted east on June 5 while temperatures lowered to near normal levels as an upper level trough pushed into California.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 99 and 103 degrees on June 3 and between 102 and 106 degrees on June 4.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge built into central California on June 22 and strengthened over the area on June 23 resulting in widespread triple digit heat across the San Joaquin Valley between June 23 and June 27. Afternoon highs in the valley ranged between 100 and 104 degrees at most locations between June 23 and June 26 and were mainly between 104 and 108 degrees on June 27 before temperatures cooled on June 28 and 29 following the passage of a strong cold front. At least one fatality could be attributed to the heat as a 27 year old man working on the Fresno State Universtiy water tower was overcome by heat stroke on June 25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on June 23-26 and between 104 and 108 degrees on June 27.

Afternoon highs in the valley ranged between 100 and 104 degrees at most locations between June 23 and June 26 and were mainly between 104 and 108 degrees on June 27 before temperatures cooled on June 28 and 29 following the passage of a strong cold front. At least one fatality could be attributed to the heat as a 27 year old man working on the Fresno State Universtiy water tower was overcome by heat stroke on June 25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 98 and 102 degrees on June 23-26 and between 102 and 106 degrees on June 27.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures reached the middle 90s with dew points in the midd to upper 70s. This produced heat index values of 105-107 degrees in portions of northwest Alabama during the mid afternoon hours of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached as high as 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains on July 10th, began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of the month, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. Very little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time period, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees during the afternoons across much of East Texas through July 12th. However, a weak surface boundary became stationary on the 13th across portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, which resulted in low level moisture pooling near and south of this boundary. Thus, even more oppressive heat indices were observed across more of East Texas on the 13th.

An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains on July 10th, began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of the month, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. Very little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time period, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees during the afternoons across much of North Central Louisiana through July 11th. However, even more oppressive heat indices were observed across much of North Louisiana on and after the 11th, with readings in excess of 110 degrees.

CZ_NAME: UPPER SANTA CRUZ RIVER AND ALTAR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on July 8th with high temperatures around 105 degrees in Santa Cruz and eastern Pima counties.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males, one near Nogales and the other within the Ironwood Forest National Monument west of Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in Santa Cruz and eastern Pima counties on July 8th. High temperatures included 108 degrees at the Tucson International Airport, 106 at Sells and 103 at Nogales.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males, one 2 miles northwest of Nogales and antoher within the Ironwood Forest National Monument.

A large upper ridge over the southwestern U.S. strengthened over California during the weekend of July 11 and 12 providing the Kern County Deserts with a period of excessive heat and the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra foothills with a period of significant heat. Afternoon temperatures were well into the triple digits in these areas during the weekend although no new records were set. Temperatures lowered some on July 13 in reponse to the ridge breaking down as a trough moved through the Pacific Northwest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 108 degrees on July 11 and July 12.

An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains on July 10th, began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of the month, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. Very little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time period, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees during the afternoons across much of North Central Louisiana through July 11th. However, even more oppressive heat indices were observed across much of North Louisiana on and after the 11th, with readings in excess of 110 degrees.

An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of July, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. A weak surface boundary became stationary on the 13th across portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, which resulted in low level moisture pooling near and south of this boundary. Thus, very oppressive heat indices were observed across much of East Texas from the 12th-13th, with heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each day.

A weak surface boundary became stationary on the 13th across portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, which resulted in low level moisture pooling near and south of this boundary. An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of July, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. The weak surface boundary that lingered across portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana gradually lifted north and dissipated by the 14th, allowing dewpoints to mix out and thus result in slightly less oppressive conditions. However, afternoon heat indices still ranged from 105 to 110 degrees on the 14th and 15th before falling below 105 degrees on July 16th.

A large upper ridge over the southwestern U.S. strengthened over California during the weekend of July 11 and 12 providing the Kern County Deserts with a period of excessive heat and the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra foothills with a period of significant heat. Afternoon temperatures were well into the triple digits in these areas during the weekend although no new records were set. Temperatures lowered some on July 13 in reponse to the ridge breaking down as a trough moved through the Pacific Northwest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 108 degrees on July 11 and July 12.

The weak surface boundary that lingered across portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana gradually lifted north and dissipated by the 14th, allowing dewpoints to mix out and thus result in slightly less oppressive conditions. However, afternoon heat indices still ranged from 105 to 110 degrees each day on the 15th and 16th before falling below 105 degrees on July 17th.

Excessive heat returned to the St. Lawrence Valley on what has already been a hot and dry early summer. High temperatures surpassed 90 degrees from July 7-10th with a record daily high of 99 degrees on July 10th. This was the 2nd highest temperature ALL-TIME at Massena, NY. In addition, high dewpoints in the upper 60s to lower 70s created heat index values at or above 100 degrees in the St. Lawrence Valley on the 9th and 10th.||In fact, Massena's max temperature for the first 10 days of July has averaged 90.8 degrees, which broke the old record of 90.3 degrees set in 1973.||Some of this excessive heat migrated into the Champlain Valley on the 8th-10th with highs in the 90s and heat index values in the mid to upper 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the 90s with dewpoints in the 60s to around 70 created heat indices in the mid to upper 90s.

An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains on July 10th, began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of the month, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. Very little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time period, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees during the afternoons across portions of Northeast Texas through July 12th. However, a weak surface trough became stationary across portions of extreme Northeast Texas, extreme Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana on the 13th, with low level moisture pooling along this boundary resulting in even more oppressive heat by this time.

Afternoon high temperatures over eastern North Dakota and the northwest quarter of Minnesota peaked in the upper 80s to mid 90s on July 24th. Combined with dew points in the middle 70s to lower 80s, heat indices over the Red River Valley rose into the 105 to 110 range during the afternoon and early evening.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in parts of southeast Arizona from June 3rd through June 5th with high temperatures exceeding established records in many locations. No heat related fatalities were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 5 to 12 degrees above normal occurred in the western deserts of Pima and southeast Pinal counties, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached. A number of daily high temperature records were tied or broken. On June 3rd, Ajo set a new record high with 108 degrees while San Manuel topped out one degree shy of a record at 103 degrees. The Tucson International Airport was two shy with a high of 105. Meanwhile, Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument and Picacho both reached 107 and Sells hit 106. On June 4th, Ajo tied a record with 110 degrees as did San Manuel with 104. The Tucson International Airport reached 108 degrees and Sells climbed to 107.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat returned to the St. Lawrence Valley on what has already been a hot and dry early summer. High temperatures surpassed 90 degrees from July 7-10th with a record daily high of 99 degrees on July 10th. This was the 2nd highest temperature ALL-TIME at Massena, NY. In addition, high dewpoints in the upper 60s to lower 70s created heat index values at or above 100 degrees in the St. Lawrence Valley on the 9th and 10th.||In fact, Massena's max temperature for the first 10 days of July has averaged 90.8 degrees, which broke the old record of 90.3 degrees set in 1973.||Some of this excessive heat migrated into the Champlain Valley on the 8th-10th with highs in the 90s and heat index values in the mid to upper 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the mid to upper 90s with dew points in the 60s to around 70 created heat indices in the mid 90s to lower 100s. Massena reached 99 degrees on July 10th, 2nd hottest ALL-TIME since records kept in 1948.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge over the southwestern U.S. strengthened over California during the weekend of July 11 and 12 providing the Kern County Deserts with a period of excessive heat and the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra foothills with a period of significant heat. Afternoon temperatures were well into the triple digits in these areas during the weekend although no new records were set. Temperatures lowered some on July 13 in reponse to the ridge breaking down as a trough moved through the Pacific Northwest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 108 degrees on July 11 and July 12.

Above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on June 21st with high temperatures around 105 degrees on the Tohono O'odham Nation. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male south of Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in south central Pima County on June 21st. High temperatures included 106 degrees at Sells and 104 degrees at Sasabe. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male 2 miles southwest of Topawa, on the Tohono O'odham Nation.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anza Borrego State Park site reports highs 111-121 degrees during the 3 day period. High of 121 degrees occurred July 12th.

A large and strong area of upper-level high pressure over the Four Corners region contributed to a period of prolonged heat across Southern California. Temperatures rose near 120 degrees across some desert locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three distressed hikers were rescued from Cedar Creek Falls Trail in San Diego County Estates, which was closed due to excessive heat. All 3 hikers were released with no injuries reported. Rescue started around 11:30 AM and finished around 1:30 PM. Temperatures during that time were between 95 and 98 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains on July 10th, began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of the month, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. Very little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time period, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees during the afternoons across much of Southwest Arkansas through July 16th.

Above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on July 5th with high temperatures just above 100 degrees in southeast Cochise County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male west of Douglas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Cochise County on July 5th. High temperatures included 101 degrees at Tombstone and 103 at McNeal. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male 5 miles west of Douglas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper ridge over the southwestern U.S. strengthened over California during the weekend of July 11 and 12 providing the Kern County Deserts with a period of excessive heat and the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Sierra foothills with a period of significant heat. Afternoon temperatures were well into the triple digits in these areas during the weekend although no new records were set. Temperatures lowered some on July 13 in reponse to the ridge breaking down as a trough moved through the Pacific Northwest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 113 degrees on July 11 and July 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains on July 10th, began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of the month, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. Very little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this time period, resulting in heat indices ranging from 105 to 110 degrees during the afternoons across much of East Texas through July 12th. However, a weak surface boundary became stationary on the 13th across portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, which resulted in low level moisture pooling near and south of this boundary. Thus, even more oppressive heat indices were observed across more of East Texas on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of July, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. The weak surface boundary that lingered across portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana gradually lifted north and dissipated by the 14th, allowing dewpoints to mix out and thus result in slightly less oppressive conditions. However, afternoon heat indices still ranged from 105 to 110 degrees each day through the 16th.

A large and strong area of upper-level high pressure over the Four Corners region contributed to a period of prolonged heat across Southern California. Temperatures rose near 120 degrees across some desert locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palm Springs ASOS reports highs 117-121 degrees during the 3 day period. High of 121 degrees occurred July 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and strong area of upper-level high pressure over the Four Corners region contributed to a period of prolonged heat across Southern California. Temperatures rose near 120 degrees across some desert locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two hikers were rescued on the Three Sisters Trail near Julian, which was had been closed due to excessive heat. The temperature was around 91 degrees at the time of the rescue (based on station that is slightly higher than elevation of trail, so actual temperature was likely warmer).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from July 10th through July 13th.  Many locations exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males, one on the western reaches of the Tohono O'odham Nation, one west of Douglas and one near Kino Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 6 to 18 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached July 10 through July 13.  A number of daily high temperature records were tied or broken. Safford Airport recorded its highest temperature ever of 115 degrees on July 11 and set new daily record highs of 111 on July 10 and 112 on July 12.  Tucson International Airport set a new daily high temperature record of 113 on July 12, which was just one degree shy of the all time hottest temperature for July.  The Tucson Airport also recorded its highest minimum temperature ever when it only dropped to 89 degrees on July 13.  On July 11 new record highs included 113 degrees at Duncan, 110 at Fort Thomas, 109 at Willcox and 103 at Sierra Vista. On July 12 new record highs included 115 degrees (tie) at Ajo, 113 at Picacho, 112 at Fort Thomas, 110 at Nogales Airport, San Simon and Willcox, 109 at McNeal and 108 at San Manuel. On July 13 new record highs included 114 degrees at Fort Thomas, 113 (tie) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 109 at Green Valley (tie) and Willcox and 107 at San Simon (tie) and Tombstone. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males, one near Kino Springs on the 10th, another 10 miles west of Douglas on the 11th, and a third near Sweetwater in the western part of the Tohono O'odham Nation on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on June 28th with high temperatures around 100 degrees on the Tohono O'odham Nation. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one young adult male south of Sells.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in south central Pima County on June 28th. High temperatures included 98 degrees at Sells and 103 degrees at Sasabe. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one young adult  male 5 miles southwest of Topawa, on the Tohono O'odham Nation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of drought conditions, strong high pressure ridging over the area, and southwest down-sloping low level winds led to hot conditions for several days across the Panhandles.  Amarillo also reached the second hottest daily maximum temperature ever by hitting 110 degrees on July 13th. Widespread temperatures of 105 to 109 degrees occurred across much the Panhandles, but Palo Duro Canyon reached excessive heat levels in excess of 110 degrees on multiple days during this stretch providing dangerous conditions for hikers in the state park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Palo Duro Canyon floor temperature equaled or exceeded 110 degrees for several hours in the afternoon and reached a maximum temperature of 115 Degrees around 1330 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of drought conditions, strong high pressure ridging over the area, and southwest down-sloping low level winds led to hot conditions for several days across the Panhandles.  Amarillo also reached the second hottest daily maximum temperature ever by hitting 110 degrees on July 13th. Widespread temperatures of 105 to 109 degrees occurred across much the Panhandles, but Palo Duro Canyon reached excessive heat levels in excess of 110 degrees on multiple days during this stretch providing dangerous conditions for hikers in the state park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Palo Duro Canyon floor temperature equaled or exceeded 110 degrees for several hours and reached a maximum temperature of 115 Degrees around 502 pm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A combination of drought conditions, strong high pressure ridging over the area, and southwest down-sloping low level winds led to hot conditions for several days across the Panhandles.  Amarillo also reached the second hottest daily maximum temperature ever by hitting 110 degrees on July 13th. Widespread temperatures of 105 to 109 degrees occurred across much the Panhandles, but Palo Duro Canyon reached excessive heat levels in excess of 110 degrees on multiple days during this stretch providing dangerous conditions for hikers in the state park.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Palo Duro Canyon floor temperature equaled or exceeded 110 degrees for several hours in the afternoon and reached a maximum temperature of 116 Degrees around 524 pm.

Along and south of a line from Carbondale to Harrisburg, a five-day stretch of hot and humid weather occurred from the 17th to the 21st. Afternoon heat indices peaked from 100 to 110 degrees each day. North of a Carbondale to Harrisburg line, heat indices exceeded 100 degrees on three consecutive days from the 17th to the 19th. A strong 500 mb high extending from west to east across the southern U.S. was responsible for the hazardous heat indices.

An upper level ridge that had been dominant over the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region to start the first couple of days of July had weakened by July 3rd, with a weak upper level disturbance sliding south into Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana. A complex of showers and thunderstorms that developed over Central and Southern Arkansas during the evening of the 2nd reinforced a weak surface trough southwest into extreme Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, and North Louisiana during the morning hours of the 3rd, with this boundary focusing an area of compressional heating and moisture pooling throughout the day. As a result, afternoon temperatures climbed into the lower to middle 90s, with limited mixing of dewpoints resulting in oppressive heat indices of 105-110 degrees across extreme Southeast Oklahoma, adjacent sections of Southwest Arkansas, extreme Northeast Texas, and Western Louisiana from late morning through the mid afternoon hours. However, showers and thunderstorms developed along this boundary by early afternoon, with this complex of storms shifting west southwest across the region during the afternoon, resulting in much cooler conditions and relief to the oppressive heat.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Intense heat fueled severe thunderstorms on the afternoon and evening of the ninth. Afternoon temperatures peaked between 105 and 110 degrees which combined with enough moisture to create isolated thunderstorms late in the afternoon. Two storms in particular both produced wind damage as they tracked to the south. ||The first storm was in the southeastern Texas Panhandle which produced a series of microbursts in Hall County. An initial severe wind gust was observed near Memphis by the Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet at 1730 CST. Approximately ten minutes later, a homestead was heavily damaged about seven miles south-southwest of Memphis. At 1810 CST, a metal building, several more homesteads, and trees were damaged along Texas State Highway 86 west of Estelline. Microburst winds were estimated between 80 and 100 mph based on the damage indicators gathered during a NWS storm survey.||A second severe storm formed south-southwest of Lubbock Preston Smith International Airport around 1930 CST. This storm then tracked to the east-southeast developing severe wind gusts within the city of Lubbock. The winds toppled a brick wall of an old roofless structure, downed power poles, and caused considerable property damage at Joyland Amusement Park. In addition, a few people were injured by falling tree limbs at Joyland.||Additionally, the intense heat required a helicopter rescue of an individual from Caprock Canyons State Park in Briscoe County. The Texas Tech University West Texas mesonet at Caprock Canyons State Park measured temperatures at high as 110 degrees Fahrenheit.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from July 10th through July 13th.  Many locations exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males, one on the western reaches of the Tohono O'odham Nation, one west of Douglas and one near Kino Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 6 to 18 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached July 10 through July 13.  A number of daily high temperature records were tied or broken. Safford Airport recorded its highest temperature ever of 115 degrees on July 11 and set new daily record highs of 111 on July 10 and 112 on July 12.  Tucson International Airport set a new daily high temperature record of 113 on July 12, which was just one degree shy of the all time hottest temperature for July.  The Tucson Airport also recorded its highest minimum temperature ever when it only dropped to 89 degrees on July 13.  On July 11 new record highs included 113 degrees at Duncan, 110 at Fort Thomas, 109 at Willcox and 103 at Sierra Vista. On July 12 new record highs included 115 degrees (tie) at Ajo, 113 at Picacho, 112 at Fort Thomas, 110 at Nogales Airport, San Simon and Willcox, 109 at McNeal and 108 at San Manuel. On July 13 new record highs included 114 degrees at Fort Thomas, 113 (tie) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 109 at Green Valley (tie) and Willcox and 107 at San Simon (tie) and Tombstone. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males, one near Kino Springs on the 10th, another 10 miles west of Douglas on the 11th, and a third near Sweetwater in the western part of the Tohono O'odham Nation on the 13th.

Temperatures soared into the 90s throughout much of eastern New York on July 19th, reaching as high as the mid to upper 90s in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys. The combination of the heat and a humid airmass brought heat indices into the 95 to 105 degree range. The heat prompted the opening of cooling centers and pools, but with reduced capacity due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. In addition, a line of thunderstorms moved in from the west during the evening, resulting in a few reports of wind damage in the Schoharie and Mid-Hudson Valleys. Heat indices exceeded 95 degrees again in some of the lower elevations of the Hudson Valley again on July 20th, but were not quite as high as the previous day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from July 29th through August 1st. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 7 to 18 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached July 29 through July 31. High temperatures on July 29 included 113 degrees at Ajo, 110 at Sells, and 109 at Picacho and Safford Airport. On July 30 highs included 115 degrees at Ajo, 113 (records) at Duncan and Safford Airport, 112 at Picacho, 111 (tie) at Sells, 110 at Tucson International Airport and 107 (record) at Nogales Airport.  On July 31 highs included 113 degrees at Ajo, 112 at Picacho and Fort Thomas (record), and 110 at Tucson International Airport and Duncan. Very hot temperatures continued on August 1st. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 30th, one near Topawa and another near San Miguel.

Along and south of a line from Carbondale to Harrisburg, a five-day stretch of hot and humid weather occurred from the 17th to the 21st. Temperatures soared into the 90s throughout much of eastern New York on July 19th, reaching as high as the mid to upper 90s in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys. The combination of the heat and a humid airmass brought heat indices into the 95 to 105 degree range. The heat prompted the opening of cooling centers and pools, but with reduced capacity due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. In addition, a line of thunderstorms moved in from the west during the evening, resulting in a few reports of wind damage in the Schoharie and Mid-Hudson Valleys. Heat indices exceeded 95 degrees again in some of the lower elevations of the Hudson Valley again on July 20th, but were not quite as high as the previous day.

Another hot and humid airmass impacted portions of eastern New York on July 27th and 28th. Heat indices reached 95 to 105 degrees on the 27th in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys. In addition, a severe thunderstorm caused an isolated wind damage report during the evening. Some areas saw relief from the heat on the 28th, but heat indices exceeded 95 degrees again for portions of the Mid-Hudson Valley. At Poughkeepsie, there were 17 days where the temperature reached 90 degrees during the month of July, tying a record. With an average temperature of 77.8 degrees, July 2020 was the hottest month on record.

An upper level ridge that had been dominant over the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region to start the first couple of days of July had weakened by July 3rd, with a weak upper level disturbance sliding south into Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana. A complex of showers and thunderstorms that developed over Central and Southern Arkansas during the evening of the 2nd reinforced a weak surface trough southwest into extreme Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, and North Louisiana during the morning hours of the 3rd, with this boundary focusing an area of compressional heating and moisture pooling throughout the day. As a result, afternoon temperatures climbed into the lower to middle 90s, with limited mixing of dewpoints resulting in oppressive heat indices of 105-110 degrees across extreme Southeast Oklahoma, adjacent sections of Southwest Arkansas, extreme Northeast Texas, and Western Louisiana from late morning through the mid afternoon hours. However, showers and thunderstorms developed along this boundary by early afternoon, with this complex of storms shifting west southwest across the region during the afternoon, resulting in much cooler conditions and relief to the oppressive heat.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from July 29th through August 1st. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 7 to 18 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached July 29 through July 31. High temperatures on July 29 included 113 degrees at Ajo, 110 at Sells, and 109 at Picacho and Safford Airport. On July 30 highs included 115 degrees at  Ajo, 113 (records) at Duncan and Safford Airport, 112 at Picacho, 111 (tie) at Sells, 110 at Tucson International Airport and 107 (record) at Nogales Airport.  On July 31 highs included 113 degrees at Ajo, 112 at Picacho and Fort Thomas (record), and 110 at Tucson International Airport and Duncan. Very hot temperatures continued on August 1st. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 30th, one near Topawa and another near San Miguel.

An upper high pressure over the Desert Southwest led to hot and dry weather for portions of the inland areas of Southern California, which contributed to heat related illness and even a fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Police responded to a call around 3:30 p.m. about a infant left inside a car on the 400 block of West Wilshire Avenue, according to the Fullerton Police Department. When officers arrived, the infant was already outside of the car but was unresponsive. The boy was pronounced dead at the scene.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper high pressure over the Desert Southwest led to hot and dry weather for portions of the inland areas of Southern California, which contributed to heat related illness and even a fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A hiker required medical rescue due to heat-related illness near doghouse Junction on Otay Mountain. Patient was airlifted to a waiting ambulance. Around 1:15 pm, temperature at Otay Mountain was 87 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from July 29th through August 1st. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 7 to 16 degrees above normal occurred in Cochise County, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached July 30 and July 31. On July 30 highs included 110 degrees at Cascabel and 107 (record) at McNeal.  On July 31 record highs included 111 degrees (tie) at Cascabel, 109 at San Simon and 106 at Tombstone. Very hot temperatures continued on August 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Heat Advisory that began on June 30th for parts of North and Central Texas continued into the first few days of July due to Heat Index values between 105 to 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon Heat Index values soared to near 105 degrees. A Heat Advisory was in effect June 30th through July 2nd.

Temperatures soared into the 90s throughout much of eastern New York on July 19th, reaching as high as the mid to upper 90s in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys. The combination of the heat and a humid airmass brought heat indices into the 95 to 105 degree range. The heat prompted the opening of cooling centers and pools, but with reduced capacity due to the ongoing coronavirus pandemic. In addition, a line of thunderstorms moved in from the west during the evening, resulting in a few reports of wind damage in the Schoharie and Mid-Hudson Valleys. Heat indices exceeded 95 degrees again in some of the lower elevations of the Hudson Valley again on July 20th, but were not quite as high as the previous day.

Another hot and humid airmass impacted portions of eastern New York on July 27th and 28th. Heat indices reached 95 to 105 degrees on the 27th in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys. In addition, a severe thunderstorm caused an isolated wind damage report during the evening. Some areas saw relief from the heat on the 28th, but heat indices exceeded 95 degrees again for portions of the Mid-Hudson Valley. At Poughkeepsie, there were 17 days where the temperature reached 90 degrees during the month of July, tying a record. With an average temperature of 77.8 degrees, July 2020 was the hottest month on record.

An upper level ridge that had been dominant over the Southern Plains and Ark-La-Tex region to start the first couple of days of July had weakened by July 3rd, with a weak upper level disturbance sliding south into Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and North Louisiana. A complex of showers and thunderstorms that developed over Central and Southern Arkansas during the evening of the 2nd reinforced a weak surface trough southwest into extreme Southeast Oklahoma, Northeast Texas, and North Louisiana during the morning hours of the 3rd, with this boundary focusing an area of compressional heating and moisture pooling throughout the day. As a result, afternoon temperatures climbed into the lower to middle 90s, with limited mixing of dewpoints resulting in oppressive heat indices of 105-110 degrees across extreme Southeast Oklahoma, adjacent sections of Southwest Arkansas, extreme Northeast Texas, and Western Louisiana from late morning through the mid afternoon hours. However, showers and thunderstorms developed along this boundary by early afternoon, with this complex of storms shifting west southwest across the region during the afternoon, resulting in much cooler conditions and relief to the oppressive heat.

Above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on July 16th with high temperatures of 95 to 100 degrees in southwest Cochise County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one teenage male near Hereford.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in southwest Cochise County on July 16th. High temperatures included 98 at Hereford and 95 at Tombstone.  US Border Patrol and Cochise County Sheriff personnel responded to a call about a companion who was suffering from heat exhaustion near Hereford.  The teenage male was found deceased. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in southeast Arizona on July 24th with high temperatures just over 100 degrees in western Pima County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for a male individual west of Ajo.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Above normal temperatures occurred in western Pima County on July 24th. High temperatures included 103 degrees at Ajo and 101 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death of the unidentified male found 20 miles west of Ajo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from July 10th through July 13th.  Many locations exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males, one on the western reaches of the Tohono O'odham Nation, one west of Douglas and one near Kino Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 6 to 18 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached July 10 through July 13.  A number of daily high temperature records were tied or broken. Safford Airport recorded its highest temperature ever of 115 degrees on July 11 and set new daily record highs of 111 on July 10 and 112 on July 12.  Tucson International Airport set a new daily high temperature record of 113 on July 12, which was just one degree shy of the all time hottest temperature for July.  The Tucson Airport also recorded its highest minimum temperature ever when it only dropped to 89 degrees on July 13.  On July 11 new record highs included 113 degrees at Duncan, 110 at Fort Thomas, 109 at Willcox and 103 at Sierra Vista. On July 12 new record highs included 115 degrees (tie) at Ajo, 113 at Picacho, 112 at Fort Thomas, 110 at Nogales Airport, San Simon and Willcox, 109 at McNeal and 108 at San Manuel. On July 13 new record highs included 114 degrees at Fort Thomas, 113 (tie) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 109 at Green Valley (tie) and Willcox and 107 at San Simon (tie) and Tombstone. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males, one near Kino Springs on the 10th, another 10 miles west of Douglas on the 11th, and a third near Sweetwater in the western part of the Tohono O'odham Nation on the 13th.

Another hot and humid airmass impacted portions of eastern New York on July 27th and 28th. Heat indices reached 95 to 105 degrees on the 27th in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys. In addition, a severe thunderstorm caused an isolated wind damage report during the evening. Some areas saw relief from the heat on the 28th, but heat indices exceeded 95 degrees again for portions of the Mid-Hudson Valley. With an average temperature of 77.8 degrees, July 2020 was the hottest month on record.

An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of July, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. A weak surface boundary became stationary on the 13th across portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, which resulted in low level moisture pooling near and south of this boundary. Thus, very oppressive heat indices were observed across North-central Louisiana from the 12th-14th, with heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each day.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from July 10th through July 13th.  Many locations exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males, one on the western reaches of the Tohono O'odham Nation, one west of Douglas and one near Kino Springs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 6 to 18 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached July 10 through July 13.  A number of daily high temperature records were tied or broken. Safford Airport recorded its highest temperature ever of 115 degrees on July 11 and set new daily record highs of 111 on July 10 and 112 on July 12.  Tucson International Airport set a new daily high temperature record of 113 on July 12, which was just one degree shy of the all time hottest temperature for July.  The Tucson Airport also recorded its highest minimum temperature ever when it only dropped to 89 degrees on July 13.  On July 11 new record highs included 113 degrees at Duncan, 110 at Fort Thomas, 109 at Willcox and 103 at Sierra Vista. On July 12 new record highs included 115 degrees (tie) at Ajo, 113 at Picacho, 112 at Fort Thomas, 110 at Nogales Airport, San Simon and Willcox, 109 at McNeal and 108 at San Manuel. On July 13 new record highs included 114 degrees at Fort Thomas, 113 (tie) at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, 109 at Green Valley (tie) and Willcox and 107 at San Simon (tie) and Tombstone. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three adult males, one near Kino Springs on the 10th, another 10 miles west of Douglas on the 11th, and a third near Sweetwater in the western part of the Tohono O'odham Nation on the 13th.

Temperatures soared into the 90s throughout the lower elevations of western Massachusetts on July 19th, reaching as high as the mid-90s. The combination of the heat and a humid airmass brought heat indices into the 95 to 105 degree range. Heat indices exceeded 95 degrees again in some of the lower elevations again on July 20th, but were not quite as high as the previous day.

An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over the Southern Plains began to amplify and expand north-northeast into the Plains and Mississippi Valley through the middle portions of July, resulting in increased subsidence and hence, hotter temperatures as readings climbed into the mid to upper 90s across much of the Ark-La-Tex. A weak surface boundary became stationary on the 13th across portions of Northeast Texas, Southern Arkansas, and North Louisiana, which resulted in low level moisture pooling near and south of this boundary. Thus, very oppressive heat indices were observed across North-central Louisiana from the 12th-14th, with heat indices ranging from 110-115 degrees each day.

A strong ridge of high pressure over the Desert Southwest led to hot temperatures in the deserts of Southern California. Temperatures ranged from just above the century mark to 117 degrees in areas of the Coachella Valley. A small wildfire broke out in the San Bernardino Mountains on July 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures ranging from 110 to 117 degrees reported in the Coachella Valley July 16th through 19th. ASOS sites at Palm Springs and Thermal both reached 117 degrees on July 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from July 29th through August 1st. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males on the Tohono O'odham Nation on July 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 7 to 18 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached July 29 through July 31. High temperatures on July 29 included 113 degrees at Ajo, 110 at Sells, and 109 at Picacho and Safford Airport. Two days in the aftermath of Hurricane Laura, very hot and humid conditions lingered across Northeast Texas through August 29th, with compressional warming ahead of a weak cool front contributing to afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, contributing to heat indices between 110 and 115 degrees across much of Northeast Texas on the 29th. Fortunately, slightly cooler and drier air filtered south in wake of the weak frontal passage to end the month of August.

An anomalously strong and expansive area of high pressure centered near the Four Corners allowed temperatures to climb up to 115 degrees, leading to excessive heat conditions. Record highs were broken in Phoenix on the 4th (114 degrees), 5th (115 degrees), and 6th (113 degrees). According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 15 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the aftermath of Hurricane Laura, very hot and humid conditions lingered across Northeast Texas on August 28th, as afternoon temperatures climbed into the mid to upper 90s. Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, resulting in heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees across Northeast Texas. Even hotter temperatures were observed on the 29th, and when combined with the oppressively humid conditions, resulted in even higher heat indices, where an Excessive Heat Warning was issued.

In the aftermath of Hurricane Laura, very hot and humid conditions lingered across East  Texas on August 28th and 29th, as afternoon temperatures climbed into the mid to upper 90s each day. Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, resulting in heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees across Lower East Texas.

A large upper high pressure center over the Desert Southwest region built northward and westward on August 14 and maintained it's grip over central California for nearly a week resulting in oppressive heat over the area for several days. An Excessive Heat Warning was posted for the San Joaquin Valley and Sierra Foothills for five days and for the Kern County Deserts for seven days as high temperatures neared record levels. In fact, several new records were set for both afternoon high temperatures and overnight high minimum temperatures in the San Joaquin Valley on August 16 and 17 with several locations reporting highs above 110 degrees F and lows above 80 degrees F.  Several cities and towns in the San Joaquin Valley, Sierra Foothills and Kern County Deserts opened their cooling centers each afternoon during this heat wave. Local emergencies were declared in Fresno, Tulare and Kings Counties due to an unusually high rate of livestock fatalities which took place between August 14 and August 18. The large high finally loosened it's grip on the area on August 21 while a northwesterly flow brought slightly cooler air into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 109 degrees on August 14-15 and August 18 and between 107 and 112 degrees on August 16-17.

Two days in the aftermath of Hurricane Laura, very hot and humid conditions lingered across extreme Northwest Louisiana through August 29th, with compressional warming ahead of a weak cool front contributing to afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s. Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, contributing to heat indices between 110 and 115 degrees across Caddo and Bossier Parishes on the 29th. Fortunately, slightly cooler and drier air filtered south in wake of the weak frontal passage to end the month of August.

Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, contributing to heat indices between 110 and 115 degrees across Caddo and Bossier Parishes on the 29th. Within a few days in the aftermath of Hurricane Laura, hot and humid conditions lingered across Northwest Louisiana from August 30th-31st, as afternoon temperatures climbed into the lower to mid 90s each day. A weak surface frontal passage moved through the area during the early morning hours of the 29th, resulting in slightly drier air to filter into the area. However, these temperatures combined with the humidity contributed to heat indices ranging from 100-103 degrees on the 30th across Caddo and Bossier Parishes, and 105-110 degrees on the 31st.  Due to the extensive power outages across much of Northwest and North-central Louisiana in wake of Laura, the NWS Shreveport Heat Advisory criteria was temporarily lowered to heat indices greater than or equal to 100 degrees for parishes where at least 10% of the parish was without power in wake of Hurricane Laura.

Southerly winds returned to East Texas on August 31st, in wake of a weak surface front that moved through the area during the early morning hours on August 30th, which filtered slightly cooler and drier air to the region. With the return of the southerly winds, higher humidity air returned in earnest as well, as temperatures climbed into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of East Texas, with the heat continuing into the first day of September.

High pressure and a dry air mass supported very hot temperatures over inland areas during this interval. Minimum temperatures were quite warm as well. The heat was occasionally tempered by high clouds streaming over the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in this zone ranged from 89 to 110 degrees. Low temperatures in this zone ranged from 46 to 66 degrees.

Anomalously strong high pressure over the Southwest led to temperatures climbing at or above 115 degrees. Temperatures peaked in Phoenix on the 30th at 118 degrees, which ended up being the hottest day of the year. Record high temperatures were set in Phoenix on the 29th, 30th, and 31st. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 26 heat-associated fatalities occurred with this heat wave. Excessive heat persisted into the beginning of August, leading to additional heat-associated fatalities.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 109 degrees on August 14-15 and August 18 and between 107 and 112 degrees on August 16-17.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Southerly winds returned to East Texas on August 31st, in wake of a weak surface front that moved through the area during the early morning hours on August 30th, which filtered slightly cooler and drier air to the region. With the return of the southerly winds, higher humidity air returned in earnest as well, as temperatures climbed into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees. When combined with the humidity, heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees across much of East Texas, with the heat continuing into the first day of September.

Within a few days in the aftermath of Hurricane Laura, hot and humid conditions lingered across Northwest Louisiana from August 30th-31st, as afternoon temperatures climbed into the lower to mid 90s each day. A weak surface frontal passage moved through the area during the early morning hours of the 29th, resulting in slightly drier air to filter into the area. However, these temperatures combined with the humidity contributed to heat indices ranging from 100-103 degrees on the 30th across Caddo and Bossier Parishes, and 105-110 degrees on the 31st.  Due to the extensive power outages across much of Northwest and North-central Louisiana in wake of Laura, the NWS Shreveport Heat Advisory criteria was temporarily lowered to heat indices greater than or equal to 100 degrees for parishes where at least 10% of the parish was without power in wake of Hurricane Laura.

A large upper high pressure center over the Desert Southwest region built northward and westward on August 14 and maintained it's grip over central California for nearly a week resulting in oppressive heat over the area for several days. An Excessive Heat Warning was posted for the San Joaquin Valley and Sierra Foothills for five days and for the Kern County Deserts for seven days as high temperatures neared record levels. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 109 degrees on August 14-15 and August 18 and between 107 and 112 degrees on August 16-17.
