CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged and oppressive heat wave swept the Central Coast and Bay Area for almost a week from August 14th to August 19th with widespread record breaking temperatures observed across the region. This was caused by a strong high pressure system over the Desert Southwest that expanded westward into California. This dome of heat brought hot temperatures to the area for several days. Multiple days of triple digit afternoon highs were recorded inland with some coastal locations even reaching the mid 90s. Several days of hot and dry weather further dried fuels over the area increasing fire danger. During this event, a surge of monsoonal and tropical moisture from a former Tropical Storm advected northward with sufficient instability to generate multiple high based and dry thunderstorms that produced several thousand lightning strikes over the Greater Bay Area. Many locations saw wind gusts of 40-50 mph with isolated areas seeing gusts of 60-75 mph. This prompted the San Francisco Bay Area forecast office to issue a rare severe thunderstorm warning. These lightning strikes in combination with gusty and erratic outflow winds sparked hundreds of wildfires across the state of California. Several smaller fires combined to form complexes some of which are now among the largest wildfires in state history. Most of which were still actively burning at the end of August. Hundreds of thousands of acres have been burned with several hundred structures destroyed as well as a handful of deaths and injuries. Tens of thousands of residents were also forced to evacuate. Additionally, all of these wildfires burning simultaneously across the state gave the Bay Area the worst air quality in the world at one point.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat across the region with widespread highs in the low 100s prompted 464 EMS calls across Santa Clara County.

In fact, several new records were set for both afternoon high temperatures and overnight high minimum temperatures in the San Joaquin Valley on August 16 and 17 with several locations reporting highs above 110 degrees F and lows above 80 degrees F.  Several cities and towns in the San Joaquin Valley, Sierra Foothills and Kern County Deserts opened their cooling centers each afternoon during this heat wave. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 113 degrees on August 14-15 and August 18-20 between 110  and 115 degrees on August 16-17.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Within a couple of days in the aftermath of Hurricane Laura, very hot and humid conditions lingered across North Louisiana from August 29th-31st, as afternoon temperatures climbed into the lower to mid 90s each day. Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, contributing to heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees each day. Due to the extensive power outages across much of North-central Louisiana in wake of Laura, the NWS Shreveport Heat Advisory criteria was temporarily lowered to heat indices greater than or equal to 100 degrees for parishes where at least 10% of the parish was without power in wake of Hurricane Laura. Unfortunately, one fatality occurred when a 52 year old man died of a heat-related illness in Grant Parish on August 31st while removing storm debris.

Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, contributing to heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees each day. Due to the extensive power outages across much of North-central Louisiana in wake of Laura, the NWS Shreveport Heat Advisory criteria was temporarily lowered to heat indices greater than or equal to 100 degrees for parishes where at least 10% of the parish was without power in wake of Hurricane Laura. Unfortunately, one fatality occurred when a 52 year old man died of a heat-related illness in Grant Parish on August 31st while removing storm debris.

Two days in the aftermath of Hurricane Laura, very hot and humid conditions lingered across Southwest Arkansas through August 29th, with compressional warming ahead of a weak cool front contributing to afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s. Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, contributing to heat indices between 110 and 115 degrees across much of Southwest Arkansas on the 29th. Fortunately, slightly cooler and drier air filtered south in wake of the weak frontal passage to end the month of August.

Anomalously strong high pressure over the Southwest led to temperatures climbing at or above 115 degrees. Temperatures peaked in Phoenix on the 30th at 118 degrees, which ended up being the hottest day of the year. Record high temperatures were set in Phoenix on the 29th, 30th, and 31st. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 26 heat-associated fatalities occurred with this heat wave. Excessive heat persisted into the beginning of August, leading to additional heat-associated fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight heat-associated fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances and location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalously strong and expansive area of high pressure centered near the Four Corners allowed temperatures to climb up to 115 degrees, leading to excessive heat conditions. Record highs were broken in Phoenix on the 4th (114 degrees), 5th (115 degrees), and 6th (113 degrees). According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 15 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

In the aftermath of Hurricane Laura, very hot and humid conditions lingered across Southeast Oklahoma on August 28th, as afternoon temperatures climbed into the mid 90s. Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, resulting in heat indices near 110 degrees across McCurtain County. Even hotter temperatures were observed on the 29th, and when combined with the oppressively humid conditions, resulted in even higher heat indices, where an Excessive Heat Warning was issued.

Strong surface high pressure over the Desert Southwest contributed to hot conditions across Southern California for the latter part of July into early August. Many locales broke records along with places in the deserts reaching over 120 degrees at times. Some areas along the coast also reported dense fog as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 100 to 110 degrees occurred across the region from July 30th through August 3rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure over the Desert Southwest contributed to hot conditions across Southern California for the latter part of July into early August. Many locales broke records along with places in the deserts reaching over 120 degrees at times. Some areas along the coast also reported dense fog as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Areas of the Coachella Valley heated up to 110 to 120 degrees during this July 30th through August 3rd heat wave, with some areas hitting over 120 degrees on July 30th and 31st. The 122 degree reading on July 31st at the Palm Springs ASOS was one degree shy of the all-time record high temperature at that location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong surface high pressure over the Desert Southwest contributed to hot conditions across Southern California for the latter part of July into early August. Many locales broke records along with places in the deserts reaching over 120 degrees at times. Some areas along the coast also reported dense fog as well.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Areas of the lower deserts of San Diego County reached 110 to 122 degrees during this July 30th through August 3rd heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of mid-level high pressure over the Southwest United States contributed to a long duration heat wave from August 14th through the 20th. Many records were broken with a couple areas receiving impacts from monsoonal thunderstorm activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures ranged from 105 to 115 degrees across the Inland Empire during this event. The Riverside Airport broke 2 daily records with this event.

Light winds and very little mixing of the air mass leftover from Laura resulted in very oppressive dewpoints in the mid and upper 70s, contributing to heat indices between 110 and 115 degrees across much of Northeast Texas on the 29th. Fortunately, slightly cooler and drier air filtered south in wake of the weak frontal passage to end the month of August.

Anomalously strong high pressure over the Southwest led to temperatures climbing at or above 115 degrees. Temperatures peaked in Phoenix on the 30th at 118 degrees, which ended up being the hottest day of the year. Record high temperatures were set in Phoenix on the 29th, 30th, and 31st. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 26 heat-associated fatalities occurred with this heat wave. Excessive heat persisted into the beginning of August, leading to additional heat-associated fatalities.

A large area of mid-level high pressure over the Southwest United States contributed to a long duration heat wave from August 14th through the 20th. Many records were broken with a couple areas receiving impacts from monsoonal thunderstorm activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of the San Diego valleys recorded temperatures of 95 to 105 degrees during this heat wave. El Cajon reported a high of 102 degrees, breaking the record for the day.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of 95 to 105 degrees were recorded during this heat event. The Laguna Hills CWOP recorded a high temperature of 107 degrees on August 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge centered over Central Texas and Eastern New Mexico began to slowly slide back to the west on August 16th, as a weak cold front began to slide southeast across Southwest Arkansas, Northeast Texas, and Northern Louisiana. However, the combination of the upper ridge providing strong sinking motion, and compressional heating just ahead of the front over East Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, and Western Louisiana, resulted in temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across these areas during the 16th. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this period of time as low level moisture pooled just ahead of the front, with resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees. These temperatures cooled slightly behind the weak mid-August cool front during the early morning hours of the 17th, providing slightly cooler but drier air through the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge centered over Central Texas and Eastern New Mexico began to slowly slide back to the west on August 16th, as a weak cold front began to slide southeast across Southwest Arkansas, Northeast Texas, and Northern Louisiana. However, the combination of the upper ridge providing strong sinking motion, and compressional heating just ahead of the front over East Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, and Western Louisiana, resulted in temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across these areas during the 16th. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this period of time as low level moisture pooled just ahead of the front, with resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees. These temperatures cooled slightly behind the weak mid-August cool front during the early morning hours of the 17th, providing slightly cooler but drier air through the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over New Mexico into Western Texas and Oklahoma expanded east into East Texas and Western Louisiana on August 13th. This strong sinking motion beneath this ridge resulted in compressional heating over these areas, with afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred, with the heat and humidity contributing to heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure aloft combined with a hot air mass already in place made for very hot conditions over southern Oregon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported high temperatures in this zone ranged from 87 to 104 degrees, and the reported low temperatures ranged from 47 to 68 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions continued from the final day in August through the first couple days of September, with temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s across Deep East Texas. Oppressively high dewpoints in the mid to upper 70s in wake of a warm frontal passage on August 31st shifted back north across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, which when combined with the very hot temperatures, resulted in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across these areas. This was brief though before areas of showers and thunderstorms ahead of a closed upper low pressure system over the Four Corners Region affected Deep East Texas on the 3rd, resulting in much cooler temperatures.

A large area of high pressure over the west brought excessive heat and dry conditions to the region. Numerous record high temperatures were broken with 13 broken records on Sunday the 6th alone including records set that weekend for the month of September. Temperatures over the long weekend breached 110 degrees across the interior with 90s along the coast to start the weekend and even reaching 100 degrees in San Francisco on Sunday. Once the ridge began to break down towards the end of the weekend, offshore winds increased flaring up some of the wildfires that were ignited during August's lightning storm. These winds also enabled smoke from various wildfires across the state to blanket much of the Bay Area. The skies were tinted orange and red with ash accumulating for many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two locations in the North Bay Valleys tied previous record high temperatures for the month of September. Kentfield with 108 degrees and Napa with 110 degrees.

Numerous record high temperatures were broken with 13 broken records on Sunday the 6th alone including records set that weekend for the month of September. Temperatures over the long weekend breached 110 degrees across the interior with 90s along the coast to start the weekend and even reaching 100 degrees in San Francisco on Sunday. Once the ridge began to break down towards the end of the weekend, offshore winds increased flaring up some of the wildfires that were ignited during August's lightning storm. These winds also enabled smoke from various wildfires across the state to blanket much of the Bay Area. The skies were tinted orange and red with ash accumulating for many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gilroy tied a previous record high for the month of September at 112 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure over the west brought excessive heat and dry conditions to the region. Numerous record high temperatures were broken with 13 broken records on Sunday the 6th alone including records set that weekend for the month of September. Temperatures over the long weekend breached 110 degrees across the interior with 90s along the coast to start the weekend and even reaching 100 degrees in San Francisco on Sunday. Once the ridge began to break down towards the end of the weekend, offshore winds increased flaring up some of the wildfires that were ignited during August's lightning storm. These winds also enabled smoke from various wildfires across the state to blanket much of the Bay Area. The skies were tinted orange and red with ash accumulating for many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The city of Richmond tied its all time record high temperature at 107 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat Advisory and Excessive Heat Warning criteria was met across the region at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hood County was under a Heat Advisory from August 30th until September 1st. Heat index values were around 105 degrees each day. Temperatures reached 100-103 each day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat Advisory and Excessive Heat Warning criteria was met across the region at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Grayson County reached Heat Advisory criteria as temperatures were between 100-105 degrees and heat index values reached 105-110 degrees each day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat Advisory and Excessive Heat Warning criteria was met across the region at the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hill County was under a Heat Advisory from August 28th until September 1st. Heat index values were around 105 degrees each day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure centered over New Mexico into Western Texas and Oklahoma expanded east into East Texas and Western Louisiana on August 13th. This strong sinking motion beneath this ridge resulted in compressional heating over these areas, with afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred, with the heat and humidity contributing to heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heat wave was forecast for the initial part of this event; however, with many massive wildfires over northern California, intense heating was suppressed to wildfire smoke. Temperatures still rose to the mid 90s and low 100s, which was not much of a reprieve from the previous week's temperatures. A heat related death occurred during this time frame on August 22. The decedent was doing yard work in heat and fell ill. He was taken to Kaiser and died 3 days later. ||In addition to lingering heat, a renewed chance of thunderstorms and fire weather concerns were forecast August 23 and 24. This generated a lot of media attention as the state just suffered from a widespread lightning event and it looked like another could form. Similar conditions were in place, with tropical moisture forecast to move over norther California; however, the system did not produce as nearly much lightning. Strikes generally remained confined, but not limited to, the west slopes of the Sierra.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Confirmed heat related death. The decedent was doing yard work in heat on August 22 and was found in his home before subsequently being taken to a local hospital. He died 3 days later. Downtown Sacramento's high temperature was 100 while Sacramento Executive was 97.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions continued from the final day in August through the first day of September, with temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s across much of East Texas. Oppressively high dewpoints in the mid to upper 70s in wake of a warm frontal passage on August 31st shifted back north across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, which when combined with the very hot temperatures, resulted in heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees across these areas. This was brief though before areas of showers and thunderstorms ahead of a closed upper low pressure system over the Four Corners Region affected much of East Texas on the 2nd, resulting in much cooler temperatures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions continued from the final day in August through the first couple days of September, with temperatures climbing into the lower and mid 90s across North Louisiana. Oppressively high dewpoints in the mid to upper 70s in wake of a warm frontal passage on August 31st shifted back north across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, which when combined with the very hot temperatures, resulted in heat indices ranging from 100-110 degrees across these areas. This was brief though before scattered showers and thunderstorms and associated cloud cover ahead of a closed upper low pressure system over the Four Corners Region affected portions of North Louisiana on the 3rd, resulting in slightly cooler conditions with lower heat indices. Due to the extensive power outages across much of Northwest Louisiana in wake of Laura, the NWS Shreveport Heat Advisory criteria was temporarily lowered to heat indices greater than or equal to 100 degrees for parishes where at least 10% of the parish was without power in wake of Hurricane Laura.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stout mid level ridge built over Deep South Texas during the last few days of August, allowing high temperatures to climb. These high temperatures combined with high surface relative humidity, allowed afternoon heat indices to climb to a dangerous 111 degrees or greater for a couple of hours in the afternoons of August 30th and 31st in populated areas along the Rio Grande.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices around McAllen, TX exceeded 111 degrees for a couple of hours starting at 1:50 PM CDT and the MFE ASOS even exceeded 116 degrees for a period of time around 4 PM CDT.

These high temperatures combined with high surface relative humidity, allowed afternoon heat indices to climb to a dangerous 111 degrees or greater for a couple of hours in the afternoons of August 30th and 31st in populated areas along the Rio Grande.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices in Cameron County exceeded 111 degrees for a couple of hours starting at 1:50 PM CDT and the BRO ASOS even exceeded 114 degrees for a period of time around 3 PM CDT, and HRL topped at 112 degrees around 2 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge centered over Central Texas and Eastern New Mexico began to slowly slide back to the west on August 16th, as a weak cold front began to slide southeast across Southwest Arkansas, Northeast Texas, and Northern Louisiana. However, the combination of the upper ridge providing strong sinking motion, and compressional heating just ahead of the front over East Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, and Western Louisiana, resulted in temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across these areas during the 16th. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this period of time as low level moisture pooled just ahead of the front, with resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees. These temperatures cooled slightly behind the weak mid-August cool front during the early morning hours of the 17th, providing slightly cooler but drier air through the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged and significant heat wave occurred in mid August due to high pressure parked over California. High temperatures soared between 100 to 115 degrees for much of the Valley and lower elevation foothills, while higher elevation areas in the mountains range from the mid 80s to low 100s. Overnight lows were oppressive during this time frame as well, with Valley and foothill locations holding in the 70s to low 80s. Many emergency room visits were recorded in the Sacramento area in addition to 3 confirmed heat related deaths. One out of these deaths also involved drug use.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager confirmed a heat related death. The deceased was a transient male that was found down at a light rail station on August 14. He was taken to a local hospital, but never recovered and died on September 2. The Coroner determined the cause of death to be distributive shock due to heat stroke due to methamphetamine overdose. The high temperature for August 14, 2020 is 106 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager confirmed a heat related death. The deceased was a transient male that was found on a local roadway on August 16. He was taken to a local hospital, but succumbed to heat related illness. The Coroner determined the cause of death to be heat related. The high temperature for August 16, 2020 is 112 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge centered over Central Texas and Eastern New Mexico began to slowly slide back to the west on August 16th, as a weak cold front began to slide southeast across Southwest Arkansas, Northeast Texas, and Northern Louisiana. However, the combination of the upper ridge providing strong sinking motion, and compressional heating just ahead of the front over East Texas, Southeast Oklahoma, and Western Louisiana, resulted in temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to in excess of 100 degrees across these areas during the 16th. Little mixing of dewpoints occurred during this period of time as low level moisture pooled just ahead of the front, with resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees. These temperatures cooled slightly behind the weak mid-August cool front during the early morning hours of the 17th, providing slightly cooler but drier air through the area.

A large area of high pressure over the west brought excessive heat and dry conditions to the region. Numerous record high temperatures were broken with 13 broken records on Sunday the 6th alone including records set that weekend for the month of September. Temperatures over the long weekend breached 110 degrees across the interior with 90s along the coast to start the weekend and even reaching 100 degrees in San Francisco on Sunday. Once the ridge began to break down towards the end of the weekend, offshore winds increased flaring up some of the wildfires that were ignited during August's lightning storm. These winds also enabled smoke from various wildfires across the state to blanket much of the Bay Area. The skies were tinted orange and red with ash accumulating for many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downtown San Francisco reached 100 degrees on Sunday breaking a previous daily record of 92 degrees in 1904.

Very hot temperatures were experienced in the lower deserts of southeast Arizona from August 24th-27th. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for four males in Pima County during the period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 9 to 12 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached August 24 through August 27. Record high temperatures were tied or set at most locations on multiple days during the period. The hottest record temperatures during this stretch were 115 degrees at Ajo on August 25; 113 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on August 25; 111 at Picacho on the 24th; 110 at Sells on the 24th; and 107 at Tucson International Airport on the 25th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for four males on August 25th, one on Ironwood National Forest grounds west of Avra Valley, one just west of there near Queen's Well on the Tohono O'odham Nation, and two near Ajo.

CZ_NAME: UPPER SANTA CRUZ RIVER AND ALTAR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from August 13th-19th. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for four adult males during the period, two each in Pima and Santa Cruz counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot and above normal temperatures around 100 degrees occurred in parts of Santa Cruz County causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on August 17. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male near Patagonia.

CZ_NAME: UPPER GILA RIVER AND ARAVAIPA VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of very hot temperatures were experienced in southeast Arizona from August 13th-19th. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for four adult males during the period, two each in Pima and Santa Cruz counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal occurred in parts of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached August 13 through August 16. Record high temperatures were tied or set at most locations on multiple days during the period. The hottest record temperatures during this stretch were 113 degrees at Safford Airport on August 15; 111 at both Fort Thomas on the 15th and 16th and Sasabe on the 14th; 110 at Duncan on the 15th; and 104 at Nogales Airport on the 13th and 15th.  The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one adult male near Ruby on August 16th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 10 to 13 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached August 13 through August 19. Record high temperatures were tied or set at most locations on multiple days during the period.  The hottest record temperatures during this stretch were 115 degrees at Ajo on August 18; 114 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on August 17 and 18; 113 at Picacho on the 18th; 111 at both Sells on the 16th and 17th and at Tucson International Airport on the 13th; 109 at Green Valley on the 17th; and 106 at San Manuel on the 14th and 15th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males, one near Guvo  on the Tohono O'odham Nation on August 13th and one on the grounds of the Ironwood National Forest on August 14th.

Record high temperatures were tied or set at most locations on multiple days during the period.  The hottest record temperatures during this stretch were 115 degrees at Ajo on August 18; 114 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on August 17 and 18; 113 at Picacho on the 18th; 111 at both Sells on the 16th and 17th and at Tucson International Airport on the 13th; 109 at Green Valley on the 17th; and 106 at San Manuel on the 14th and 15th. Low temperatures during this period were as warm as 84 at Tucson and 89 at Ajo. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males, one near Guvo  on the Tohono O'odham Nation on August 13th and one on the grounds of the Ironwood National Forest on August 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in the lower deserts of southeast Arizona from August 24th-27th. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for four males in Pima County during the period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 9 to 12 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached August 24 through August 27. Record high temperatures were tied or set at most locations on multiple days during the period. The hottest record temperatures during this stretch were 115 degrees at Ajo on August 25; 113 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on August 25; 111 at Picacho on the 24th; 110 at Sells on the 24th; and 107 at Tucson International Airport on the 25th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for four males on August 25th, one on Ironwood National Forest grounds west of Avra Valley, one just west of there near Queen's Well on the Tohono O'odham Nation, and two near Ajo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A abnormally strong ridge and dry soil brought record heat to western and central Wyoming. Many areas saw record high temperatures, with a few stations reaching 100 degrees. All time monthly high temperatures were set or tied at Big Piney, Casper, Lander, Riverton, Rock Springs and Worland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An all time September record high temperature of 91 degrees was set at Big Piney, Wyoming. This broke the old record of 87 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stout mid level ridge built over Deep South Texas during the last few days of August and into the beginning of September, allowing high temperatures to climb. These high temperatures combined with high surface relative humidity, allowed afternoon heat indices to climb to a dangerous 111 degrees or greater for a couple of hours in the afternoon of September 1st in populated areas of the Rio Grande Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High afternoon temperatures combined with high relative humidity values to create heat indices that exceeded 111 degrees Fahrenheit for a couple of hours in Brownsville, Harlingen, and the surrounding areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A abnormally strong ridge and dry soil brought record heat to western and central Wyoming. Many areas saw record high temperatures, with a few stations reaching 100 degrees. All time monthly high temperatures were set or tied at Big Piney, Casper, Lander, Riverton, Rock Springs and Worland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Natrona County, Wyoming airport had a record high temperature of 98 degrees. This was a record high for the day and also tied the all time September high temperature.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A abnormally strong ridge and dry soil brought record heat to western and central Wyoming. Many areas saw record high temperatures, with a few stations reaching 100 degrees. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lander, Wyoming airport had a high temperature of 96 degrees. This broke the all time September record of 95 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Worland, Wyoming airport reached a high temperature of 100 degrees, tying the all-time September record.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: All time high month of September temperatures were set in Pocatello, Idaho Falls, Challis, and Burley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperature at the Pocatello Regional Airport on September 5th was 100 degrees.  This was the first 100 degree temperature ever recorded in September and broke the old hottest temperature record for the month of 98 degrees set in 2017.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: All time high month of September temperatures were set in Pocatello, Idaho Falls, Challis, and Burley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperatures reached 97 degrees at Idaho Falls Regional Airport on September 5th.   This tied the previous record for hottest September temperature ever set in 1950.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stout mid level ridge built over Deep South Texas during the last few days of August and into the beginning of September, allowing high temperatures to climb. EVENT_NARRATIVE: High afternoon temperatures combined with high relative humidity values to create heat indices that exceeded 111 degrees Fahrenheit for a couple of hours in Zapata and the surrounding areas. Heat indices even briefly exceeded 116 degrees around 5 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions continued from the final day in August through the first day of September, with temperatures climbing into the mid 90s across Northwest Louisiana. Oppressively high dewpoints in the mid to upper 70s in wake of a warm frontal passage on August 31st shifted back north across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, which when combined with the very hot temperatures, resulted in heat indices ranging from 100-110 degrees across these areas. This was brief though before scattered showers and thunderstorms and associated cloud cover ahead of a closed upper low pressure system over the Four Corners Region affected Northwest Louisiana on the 2nd, resulting in slightly cooler conditions with lower heat indices. Due to the extensive power outages across much of Northwest Louisiana in wake of Hurricane Laura, the NWS Shreveport Heat Advisory criteria was temporarily lowered to heat indices greater than or equal to 100 degrees for parishes where at least 10% of the parish was without power.

A large high pressure center that was centered over the four corners region strengthened on September 4 and brought near record high temperatures to eastern Kern County. The high strengthened further on September 5 and provided the San Jaoquin Valley and the Sierra foothills as well as the Kern County Desert areas with a period of oppressive heat during the Labor Day holiday weekend between September 5 and 7. A low pressure system dropped from western Canada into the Great Basin on September 8 resulting in lowering temperatures across the area as the large high weakened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 108 and 112 degrees on September 4-6.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions continued from the final day in August through the first few days of September, with temperatures climbing into the mid 90s across North-central Louisiana. Oppressively high dewpoints in the mid 70s in wake of a warm frontal passage on August 31st shifted back north across much of East Texas and North Louisiana, which when combined with the very hot temperatures, resulted in heat indices ranging from 100-107 degrees across these areas. This was brief though before scattered showers and thunderstorms and associated cloud cover ahead of a closed upper low pressure system over the Four Corners Region affected portions of North Louisiana on the 3rd, resulting in slightly cooler conditions with lower heat indices. Due to the extensive power outages across much of North Louisiana in wake of Hurricane Laura, the NWS Shreveport Heat Advisory criteria was temporarily lowered to heat indices greater than or equal to 100 degrees for parishes where at least 10% of the parish was without power.

The hottest record temperatures during this stretch were 115 degrees at Ajo on August 18; 114 at Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument on August 17 and 18; 113 at Picacho on the 18th; 111 at both Sells on the 16th and 17th and at Tucson International Airport on the 13th; 109 at Green Valley on the 17th; and 106 at San Manuel on the 14th and 15th. Low temperatures during this period were as warm as 84 at Tucson and 89 at Ajo. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two adult males, one near Guvo  on the Tohono O'odham Nation on August 13th and one on the grounds of the Ironwood National Forest on August 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass was in place across the region. This resulted in scattered thunderstorms during the afternoon and evening of August 10th. Some of these storms became severe, with one storm producing an EF1 tornado in Washington County. The storms also produced flash flooding in Ulster County. Heat indices reached the 95 to 100 degree range across the advisory area on Monday, August 10th with heat indices of the same magnitude subdued further south during the afternoon hours of August 11th.

A toddler died in Las Vegas when she was accidentally locked in a car on a hot day.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 22 month old girl was accidentally locked in a car, and died of heat related causes. The high temperature in Las Vegas was in the mid 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface area of high pressure situated over the Great Basin brought very warm conditions with gusty Santa Ana winds across the region, along with patchy dense fog nights and mornings over the coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some areas hit close to 100 degrees during this heat wave from the 12th to the 16th. Chula Vista recorded 93 degrees on the 13th, tying the daily record high.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface area of high pressure situated over the Great Basin brought very warm conditions with gusty Santa Ana winds across the region, along with patchy dense fog nights and mornings over the coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some areas recorded temperatures near 100 degrees during this heat wave from the 12th to the 16th. Santa Ana set a daily record high temperature on the 14th, hitting 96 degrees.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface area of high pressure situated over the Great Basin brought very warm conditions with gusty Santa Ana winds across the region, along with patchy dense fog nights and mornings over the coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures of over 100 degrees were reported from the 12th through the 16th. The Riverside Municipal Airport (KRAL) ASOS tied a record daily high of 101 degrees on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface area of high pressure situated over the Great Basin brought very warm conditions with gusty Santa Ana winds across the region, along with patchy dense fog nights and mornings over the coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Prevalent 90s and near 100 degree readings were recorded during this heat wave from the 12th to the 16th. Escondido tied their daily record high of 101 degrees on the 16th.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of upper level high pressure formed over the Southwestern U.S. and brought some major heat to inland areas of Southern California June 2nd through 4th. Many places went over the century mark from the Inland Empire to the deserts. Palm Springs reached 115 degrees on June 3rd, which is 17 degrees above average and 3 degrees from the record for that date.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures ranged from 95 to 106 degrees across the Inland Empire June 2nd through 4th. Chino Airport hit 106 degree and Ontario Airport reached 102 both on June 3rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two young children entered their father's truck by themselves during the afternoon of June 13th in Tulsa, Oklahoma. They became locked in the vehicle for about five hours, and were found dead that evening, having succumbed to the extreme heat in the locked truck. The high temperature reached 94 degrees that afternoon in Tulsa.

The 2nd longest heatwave in modern history (1900-onward) occurred across portions of NY and VT from June 18th through June 23rd. Temperatures exceeded 90 degrees for up to 6 consecutive days in portions of the St. Lawrence and Champlain Valleys. Daily High temperature records were set at Massena on June 22nd and June 23rd with high temperatures of 93 and 92 degrees respectively.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s for many parts of the St. Lawrence Valley for six days with increasing humidity on the tail end of this stretch, bringing heat indices into the mid 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the 90s...along with dewpoints ranging from around 60 to the lower 60s...combined to produce apparent temperatures in the mid to upper 90s across portions of the region. The actual high temperature of 96 at Caribou tied the all time record high. The actual high temperature of 95 at Houlton established a new daily record.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the lower to mid 90s...along with dewpoints from around 60 to the lower 60s...combined to produce apparent temperatures in the mid to upper 90s. The actual high temperature of 95 in Houlton established a new daily record.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures in the upper 80s to lower 90s for the deeper valleys of the Connecticut River Valley for six days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures and high humidity led to heat advisories on the 30th, with multiple heat-related illnesses reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A total of 5 people were treated for heat-related illnesses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large ridge of high pressure remained situated near the Four Corners region for several days. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across eastern Utah. Precipitable water values were at a record low for mid July which translated to single digit humidity at the surface. Record breaking high temperatures occurred through the period with overnight lows only dropping into the low to mid 80s below 5000 feet in the Arches and Grand Flat area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 104 to 109 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations at elevations below 5000 feet on July 11th, 12th and 13th. Additionally, overnight lows ranged from 80 to 83 degrees on the morning of the 12th and 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures were experienced in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona from September 4th-7th. Many locations approached or exceeded 110 degrees and set new daily record high temperatures. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for five individuals found in the desert in Pima and Cochise counties during the period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 10 to 13 degrees above normal occurred in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached September 4 through September 7. Record high temperatures were tied or set at most locations on multiple days during the period. The hottest record temperatures during this stretch were 115 degrees at Ajo on September 6; 114 at Ajo on the 4th and 5th, and at Picacho on the 5th; 113 at Picacho on the 6th; and 112 at Picacho and Sells on the 4th; 110 at Tucson International Airport on the 4th; 109 at Green Valley on the 4th and 5th; and 107 at Fort Thomas on the 5th, and at Safford Airport on the 7th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals on the Tohono O'odham Nation--a female east of Sells on the 4th and a male north of Hickiwan on the 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridging pattern remained locked in place across the Desert Southwest during this time period, producing a long lasting heat wave from September 29th to October 5th. Daily record highs were tied or broken for seven consecutive days at various sites across Southern California with this excessive heat event. The Candy Fire burned some areas of vegetation in the Inland Empire.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread 90s and low 100s were reported with this event. The San Diego Airport ASOS hit 96 degrees on September 30th and 97 degrees on October 1st, breaking the daily record highs both days.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridging pattern remained locked in place across the Desert Southwest during this time period, producing a long lasting heat wave from September 29th to October 5th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures rose over the century mark across the Inland Empire during this heat wave. The Riverside Airport ASOS reached 108 degrees on the 30th, tying the daily record high.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong upper level high pressure became positioned over California along with an offshore flow in Southern California resulting in record very hot temperatures. September 5th and 6th were the hottest and several all-time highs were broken. The Valley and the El Dorado wildfires also started on Saturday September 5th, which scorched parts of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures across the Inland Empire ranged from 110 to over 120 degrees for this event. The Riverside ASOS reported 117 degrees on the 5th and 6th, breaking two daily record highs. The Chino ASOS reported 121 degrees on the 6th, making it the hottest temperature ever recorded in the Inland Empire.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong upper level high pressure became positioned over California along with an offshore flow in Southern California resulting in record very hot temperatures. September 5th and 6th were the hottest and several all-time highs were broken. The Valley and the El Dorado wildfires also started on Saturday September 5th, which scorched parts of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Parts of the area rose up to 110 to 115 degrees during this time period. The Ramona ASOS broke two daily record highs on the 5th and 6th, reaching 112 degrees each day.|Escondido had an all-time high of 115F. On September 6th, an all-time high of 113 was recorded at Alpine on September 5th. San Diego county Public Health recorded significant (77) hospitalizations due to the excessive heat.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures over 100 degrees occurred across the region during this heat wave. El Cajon reached 107 degrees on the 30th, breaking the daily record high temperature.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 110 degrees in the afternoon and early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong upper level high pressure became positioned over California along with an offshore flow in Southern California resulting in record very hot temperatures. September 5th and 6th were the hottest and several all-time highs were broken. The Valley and the El Dorado wildfires also started on Saturday September 5th, which scorched parts of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Parts of the lower deserts reported highs above 110 degrees during this time period. The peak of the heat was on the 5th and 6th, where some areas hit close to the 120 degree mark. Anza Borrego State Park broke daily record highs on the 5th and 6th, reaching 117 degrees both days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of unseasonably high temperatures was observed in southeast California during the middle of August. Daily afternoon temperatures reached up to 105-115 each day, with lows only falling into the upper-70s to low-80s. A heat-caused fatality was reported in Joshua Tree National Park on the 20th after an individual's vehicle became disabled along an unmaintained road intended for 4x4 vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: During a record-setting month for heat, a prolonged period of unseasonably high temperatures was observed during the middle of the month. Afternoon temperatures were reaching upwards of 105-115 degrees each day and only cooling off into the upper-70 to low-80s in the mornings. On the 20th, at the end of this week and a half long stretch of heat, the body of a 42 year old male was discovered next to a sedan along Black Eagle Mine Road in Joshua Tree National Park by park visitors. It appeared the man's vehicle became disabled/stuck on the unpaved and unmaintained road that is intended for 4x4 vehicles. Park officials deemed the fatality heat-caused and said that the man likely died several hours before being found.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During early September, from the 4th through the 7th, southeast California experienced some of its hottest temperatures of the prolific 2020 heat season. This excessive heat episode lined up with the Labor Day holiday weekend. Temperatures through the weekend reached up to 115-122 degrees across the region with the hottest day occurring on the 5th. A young individual succumbed to the heat and passed away after setting out on a hike in Joshua Tree National Park during the afternoon of the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An excessive heat event occurred over Labor Day weekend. Afternoon temperatures reached up to 115-122 degrees across the area and morning lows only fell to around 80 degrees. The hottest day of the entire 2020 heat season occurred on the 5th. In Joshua Tree National Park, three individuals set out on a hike around noon on the 5th in the Turkey Flats area. One of the hikers, a 20 year old male, became unconscious and one of the others called authorities for immediate aid at 1900 PDT. Temperatures were still over 100 degrees well into the evening. Park authorities located the hikers around 2330 PDT and administered CPR to the unconscious hiker, but were unable to revive him. The hiker was later pronounced dead at around 0900 PDT on the 6th with the cause of death being heat-caused. The other two hikers were successfully rescued.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the region led to a stretch of hot days from August 14 through August 17. Hot temperatures resulted in many people seeking locations to cool off in local rivers, which lead to two drownings as well as multiple people going to local hospitals for treatment of typical heat-related medical symptoms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures across the area reached into the upper 90s and low 100s. This lead to many people seeking locations to cool off. As a result, a person died Monday August 17 after jumping into the Clackamas River in Estacada, Oregon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure centered near the Four Corners allowed for temperatures to climb above 110 degrees each day, leading to excessive heat conditions. Record highs were set in Phoenix on the 24th (115 degrees) and on the 27th (113 degrees). According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 20 heat-associated fatalities occurred with this event.

A very strong and expansive area of high pressure remained situated over the Desert Southwest for multiple days, allowing for temperatures to reach or exceed 115 degrees most days during this time. Record highs were set nearly everyday in Phoenix during this time with records broken on the 13th, 14th, 16th, 17th, 18th, and 19th. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 43 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this heat wave.

A very strong area of high pressure parked over the Southwest United States led to continued excessive heat conditions across the region from the end of July into the beginning of August. Temperatures each day climbed near or above 110 degrees with a daily record high of 114 degrees being set in Phoenix on the 3rd. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 40 heat-associated fatalities occurred with this event for the beginning of August.

A very strong area of high pressure parked over the Southwest United States led to continued excessive heat conditions across the region from the end of July into the beginning of August. Strong high pressure over the region allowed for temperatures to reach excessive heat conditions for multiple days across southeast California. A heat-caused fatality was reported in Joshua Tree National Park on the 20th after an individual's vehicle became disabled along an unmaintained road intended for 4x4 vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On the 20th, at the end of a multi-day excessive heat event, the body of a 42 year old male was discovered next to a sedan along Black Eagle Mine Road in Joshua Tree National Park by park visitors. It appeared the man's vehicle became disabled/stuck on the unpaved and unmaintained road that is intended for 4x4 vehicles. Park officials deemed the fatality heat-caused and said that the man likely died several hours before being found.

Temperatures during this period of excessive heat reached upwards of around 115-120 degrees across the region. A young individual succumbed to the heat and passed away after setting out on a hike in Joshua Tree National Park during the afternoon of the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An excessive heat event occurred over the Labor Day weekend as afternoon temperatures climbed upwards of 115-120 degrees across the area. In Joshua Tree National Park, two individuals set out on a hike around noon on the 5th in the Turkey Flats area. One of the hikers, a 20 year old male, became unconscious and the other called authorities for immediate aid at 1900PDT. Park authorities located the hikers around 2330PDT and administered CPR to the unconscious hiker, but were unable to revive him. The hiker was later pronounced dead at around 0900PDT on the 6th with the cause of death being heat-caused.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalously strong and expansive area of high pressure centered near the Four Corners allowed temperatures to climb up to 115 degrees, leading to excessive heat conditions. Record highs were broken in Phoenix on the 4th (114 degrees), 5th (115 degrees), and 6th (113 degrees). According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 15 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One heat-associated fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances and location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong and expansive area of high pressure remained situated over the Desert Southwest for multiple days, allowing for temperatures to reach or exceed 115 degrees most days during this time. Record highs were set nearly everyday in Phoenix during this time with records broken on the 13th, 14th, 16th, 17th, 18th, and 19th. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 43 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this heat wave.

Anomalously strong high pressure over the Southwest led to temperatures climbing at or above 115 degrees. Temperatures peaked in Phoenix on the 30th at 118 degrees, which ended up being the hottest day of the year. Record high temperatures were set in Phoenix on the 29th, 30th, and 31st. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 26 heat-associated fatalities occurred with this heat wave. Excessive heat persisted into the beginning of August, leading to additional heat-associated fatalities.

Strong high pressure building over the Southwest at the end of May led to several days of excessive heat warning conditions as temperatures approached and exceeded 110 degrees. On the 29th, Phoenix topped out at 112 degrees, tying the daily high temperature record for the date. A very strong area of high pressure parked over the Southwest United States led to continued excessive heat conditions across the region from the end of July into the beginning of August. Temperatures each day climbed near or above 110 degrees with a daily record high of 114 degrees being set in Phoenix on the 3rd. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 40 heat-associated fatalities occurred with this event for the beginning of August.
